bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter, Jr., to Philip Showalter Hench, February 23, 1948

div1.p: Carter, Jr., says his father's letters will give Hench interesting data. He suggests that Stitt and Williams might be able to help Hench find more information concerning what his father did in controlling yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter, Jr., to Philip Showalter Hench, February 23, 1948
div1.opener:
HENRY R. CARTER, JR., M. D.
WOODWARD BUILDING
BIRMINGHAM 3, ALA.
February 23, 1948
Dr. P. S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
102-110 Second Avenue, S.W.
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I am happy to tell you that the reprint has been recieved and that it
was a real pleasure to read and reread it over the weekend. I wont to
thank you also for sending me the Conquerors of Yellow Fever.

Father's letter will give you some interesting data, but he was a person
who always said little about himself.

You mentioned Adm. Stitt, he knew father and was familiar with father's
work in yellow fever, also L. L. Williams of the retired officers of the
U.S.P.H.S. trained under father and took over malaria control when
father was retired. Any one of these will be able to refer you to others
who can and gladly will give you all data obtainable showing what father
did in controlling yellow fever.

I am very thankful that you were selected to write the paper on yellow
fever for you wish to give credit to those who have done their parts as
well as Col Walter Reed.

If there is anything I can do to help please let me know for it will be
a pleasure to help you.

closer.signed: Henry R. Carter, Jr., M. D.
